Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Warner and his team continue their existing program to produce about 100 asteroid lightcurves per year. Lightcurve observations measure the changes in light from an asteroid over time, and are among the productive research projects that can be done with modest instrument (less than 0.5-m) telescopes and high-end commercial CCD cameras. Smaller telescopes can obtain lightcurves for modeling of objects as small as about 2-5 km and up to the largest asteroids. Lightcurve observations are obtained in a few days to weeks, and from these data it is possible to determine the rotation rate of an asteroid, its taxonomic class based on multi-color photometry, absolute magnitude (and thus its approximate size), surface light scattering properties, and sometimes an initial indication of its shape and the spin axis orientation. These characteristics provide constraints on theories regarding the development and evolution of the asteroids within our Solar System.
The results help to understand two processes involving the thermal re-radiation of sunlight by asteroids: First, the Yarkovsky effect, which changes the size of an object's orbit and, second, the YORP effect (Yarkovsky-O'Keefe-Radzievskii-Paddack), which is believed to be responsible for aligning the spin axes within asteroid groups or families. The YORP effect is thought to be the primary mechanism for forming small binary asteroids by causing a parent asteroid to spin up to a point where it sheds mass that becomes a satellite. . The project has also lead to the discovery of a dozen binary asteroids, and more discoveries might follow. The new lightcurve data are used to develop ideas on binary formation, spin axis orientation, and orbital migration, along with more clearly defining the role of the Yarkovsky and YORP effects on asteroid evolution.
Dr. Warner and his team coordinate their efforts with other lightcurve and binary search programs through regularly published quarterly articles in the Minor Planet Bulletin that lists potential targets; the CALL (Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link) web site that lists targets and provides a 'reservation' system to help coordinate observing efforts; and through maintaining the asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB). This database gives up-to-date results of all lightcurve results and is frequently used by other researchers. This project engages a large number of high school and undergraduate students and faculty at educational institutions around the world, as well as the general public ('backyard astronomers') in astronomical research.

One of the more fundamental properties of an asteroid is how fast it rotates. Knowing the rotation period of an asteroid can tell us even more about it. For example, if a “day” on an asteroid is only 1 hour, then it must be held together by forces stronger than those that would make if fly apart. In this case, it’s what’s called “strength-bound.” On the other hand, almost any asteroid with a rotation period longer than about 2.2 hours is mostly likely a “rubble pile”, something like a large bean bag held together only by the self-gravitation of its many parts.

The work on the asteroid lightcurve database (LCDB) catalogs rotation rates so that researchers can know the value for a single asteroid or examine trends based on other properties such as its diameter, chemical makeup, distance from the Sun, and so on. These efforts have led to a better understanding of how our Solar System came to be and how it is still changing. They also helped in assessing the potential risk for an asteroid impact by understanding forces other than gravity that affect rotation rates and the orbits of asteroids.

In recent years, studying those asteroids that present the greatest potential threat, the near-Earth asteroids (NEA), has come to the fore, with substantial amounts of money to given to all-sky and wide-field surveys that are dedicated, at least in part, to finding the next level of objects posing a threat to planet Earth: those with an effective diameter down to about 140 meters. While these do not pose a global threat, an impact by a body this size would cause wide-spread destruction on a regional level. The information stored in the LCDB includes not only rotation rates but other information, among them being the estimated size.

Co-I Alan Harris and colleagues have used the information in the LCDB along with reports on the number of objects found by the large surveys to estimate the percentage of asteroids of a given size that are thought to exist and have actually been discovered. Going to a broader view, Harris et al. estimated how long it will take to reach stated policy goals for asteroid discovery and the overall efficiency of the surveys. These results will play a strong role as policy makers decide how to fund existing and future surveys and determine the limits in terms of cost versus benefits.

Starting in 2013, the first year of the proposal, there were about 4800 asteroids with periods known well enough for statistical studies of rotation rates. In early 2015, the number was more than 5500. Then the surveys came. With the publication of two papers using data from a wide-field survey called the Palomar Transit Factory, more than 13000 periods were added to the LCDB. About 9900 of those entries were the first time a period had been reported for the object.

In 2011, we published a paper that examined the potential biases that might be introduced by such a large influx of data from wide-field surveys where the observing strategy results in a relatively small number of observations over a period of only a few days, what are called “sparse data sets.” The results from these two papers provided the perfect chance to check our predictions.

We analyzed rotation period statistics with and without the large wide-field data set. We found several results that, together, may help determine the future course for such surveys. 1) The statistics did not change significantly when adding the wide-field data. 2) As we expected in our 2011 paper, there were strong biases against fast and slowly spinning asteroids, those with a period of < 3 hours and > 100 hours. 3) There was a strong bias against objects with lightcurves of low amplitude.
